Name: Ethiopia Hambela Natural
Review: ong>A fine dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia profile: part yellow guava nectar, part crisp unsweetened chocolate, part sweetly shimmering floral top notes.

Name: Rum-Barrel Conditioned Ethiopia Gelena Abaya
Review: ong>Grind this coffee and it will fill the house with heady sweet rum aromas, which fatten, complicate and round in the cup with continued intensity but impressive poise and elegance. An unusually explicit and successful experiment with cask-conditioned coffee.
Coffee Origin: Kersa district, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Peru Cajamarca
Review: ong>Those who value gentle grace and subtlety in a silky, balanced cup.

Name: Finca La Mula Panama Geisha
Review: ong>A splendid, over-the-top, almost hallucinatory version of the great Gesha profile. Aficionados with substantial coffee budgets should not miss it.

Name: Milepost Kenya Nyeri Ruarai
Review: ong>A brilliant, challenging coffee, juicy and bright, thrilling to those who can handle the sweetly pungent, cleanly fruit-toned intensity.

Name: Ethiopia Worka Natural
Review: ong>An unusually delicate though intricate dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia. Exhilarating but subtle.

Name: Kenya Thiriku
Review: ong>Big, grandly generous, juicy Kenya. A versatile coffee; should be a crowd-pleaser.

Name: Kenya Muiri Estate
Review: ong>Those who enjoy resonance and savory-sweet complexity in a deep, vibrant version of the great Kenya profile.

Name: Ari-Ari Seuri-Seuri
Review: ong>Those who enjoy intricate flavor and a structure that combines the opulently lush with the bracingly brisk.

Name: Jazz Apricot (Espresso)
Review: ong>A classic espresso gone supernova, both seductive and challenging.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo and Yirgacheffe, Ethiopia; Kenya; Sumatra.

Name: Ethiopia Biloya Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy being seduced and dazzled.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Organic Ethiopian Worka Special Prep
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a plush, round, nectar-like cup with an edge of crisp complication.

Name: Colombia Las Hermosas
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the poised balance and gentle brightness of a pure and classic Colombia.

Name: Burundi Buhorwa
Review: ong>Those who value a cleanly elegant variation on the sweet-savory resonance of Central Africa Great Lakes coffees.

Name: Papua New Guinea Ulya Wahgi Valley
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a delicate but deeply expressed, subtly original cup.
Coffee Origin: Wahgi Valley, Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea.

Name: Dukorere Ikawa Cooperative Burundi
Review: ong>Those who value juicy sweetness, syrupy mouthfeel and graceful balance in a very clean Burundi.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Aricha
Review: ong>A fine variant on the dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia style, simultaneously lyrically sweet and crisply austere.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Aricha Natural
Review: ong>An intriguing variation on the dried-in-the-fruit or natural-processed Ethiopia cup, simultaneously lush yet crisp.

Name: Rwanda Musasa Fair Trade
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a profound natural sweetness in a Fair-Trade-certified coffee. Sweeter and more delicate than a typical good Rwanda.

Name: Peru Cajamarca Fair Trade/Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy poised delicacy and subtle complexity in a Fair Trade- and organic-certified coffee.

Name: Colombia Alto del Obispo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classically sweet and vibrantly citrusy Colombia.
Coffee Origin: San AgustÃ­n growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Brazil Pocas de Caldas Rainha Natural
Review: ong>A fine rendition of the classic Brazil dried-in-the-fruit, natural-processed cup.
Coffee Origin: Mogiana Region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Reserve 100% Panama Geisha
Review: ong>An unusual opportunity to taste the celebrated Gesha profile in a very dark-roasted preparation. Think cedar-planked fruit-toned bon-bon.

Name: Bolivia Finca Las Tacanas
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a deeply pungent, resonantly fruit-toned coffee originating from an unusual program that invites both visual and sensory intimacy with the coffee source.

Name: Rwanda Bufcafe Bourbon Lot
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the tartly sweet sensations: orange marmalade, for example. The acidity here is enveloped in a rich sweetness and complicated by crisp, cinnamon-like aromatic wood.

Name: Kenya Gakui Peaberry
Review: ong>Fine variation on the great Kenya cup, delicate but vivid with sweet flowers and tart berry.

Name: Guatemala Medium Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy balance, depth, and gently rounded acidity in a quietly complex cup.

Name: Rwanda Kinyaga Co-op
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a rich, sweet-toned, deeply expressed cup; aficionados who value a particularly refined version of the classic Rwanda style.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe Alemu Station
Review: ong>A big, soaring, intense version of the floral and brightly fruit-toned Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Worka Coop Alemu
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a softly intricate coffee with crisp floral and cacao nib suggestions overlaying a lush, almost overripe fruit.

Name: Rwanda Kanzu Lot #13
Review: ong>A particularly deeply expressed example of the sweet-savory, resonantly complex Rwanda cup.

Name: Kenya Kianjuri AB
Review: ong>A resonant coffee that particularly rewards patient drinking, allowing full disclosure of the layered depth of pungent fruit and sweet flowers.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Tambaya Peaberry
Review: ong>A fine variation on the Kenya theme of juicy, berryish sweetness fused with the dry, savory and crisp. Aficionados of the classic Kenya style should particularly enjoy it.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Idido Natural
Review: ong>A refined dried-in-the-fruit ânaturalâ processed Yirgacheffe that gracefully balances crisp cacao and nut notes with complex, musky flowers.

Name: Espresso Crema Dolce
Review: ong>The deep, sweetly pungent straight shot is particularly fine in cappuccino-sized milk.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Konga Natural (Single-Serve Capsule)
Review: ong>This crisp yet sweet, delicately complex cup gives Keurig owners a quiet yet still engaging suggestion of the lush intrigue of fine southern Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit coffees.
Coffee Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Fifth Avenue Medium (Single-Serve Capsule)
Review: ong>Keurig-owners who value a gently brisk cup with pleasing hints of ripe orange and nut.

Name: Elevasio (Single-Serve Capsule)
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the strongly stated cup brewed by the Nespresso VirtuoLine system, in this case a cup that forcefully foregrounds a pungently tart character complicated by fruit-toned nuance.

Name: Taitung Guanshan Lot 12 (Single-Serve Capsule)
Review: ong>Keurig owners who value a cup with subtly complex, original aromatics from a very unusual coffee origin.

Name: Sumatran Reserve Extra Bold (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Keurig owners who enjoy the earthy and malty chocolate character of a classic old-fashioned Sumatra.

Name: Costa Rica Tarrazu Montecielo (Single-Serve Capsule)
Review: ong>Keurig-owners who enjoy delicacy and balance.

Name: Whidbey Blend (Single-Serve Capsule)
Review: ong>Excellent dark roast for Keurig owners, roasty but balanced and lively.

Name: Ethiopian Sidamo Monk-Shot (Single-Serve Capsule)
Review: ong>Not a characteristic Ethiopia cup, but appealingly deep with crisp bakerâs chocolate and cedar notes.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Aria Blend Blonde Roast (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Keurig owners who enjoy a brisk, citrusy cup; not the usual roasty Starbucks cup.

Name: Colombia Luminosa (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A very slightly darkish edge to the roast complicates without muting a bracing, brisk Colombia for Keurig owners.
Coffee Origin: Huila Department, southwestern Colombia; southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Konga
Review: ong>An elegant balance of dry chocolate and sweet orange and flowers animates this cleanly crisp dried-in-the-fruit Yirgacheffe.
Coffee Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Signature Blend CafÃ©
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classic espresso with a sweet-toned dark chocolate enveloping crisp nut and aromatic fir notes. Excellent in cappuccino-sized milk.

Name: Panama Los Lajones Natural
Review: ong>A classic medium roast develops an engaging and original balance of crisply dry unsweetened chocolate and sweet orange and musky, grappa-like notes.
Coffee Origin: Eastern slopes of Volcan Baru, western Panama.

Name: House Blend CafÃ©
Review: ong>This traditional-style medium-dark-roasted espresso is particularly impressive in cappuccino-scale milk.

Name: Kenya AB Chania Estate Washed
Review: ong>Those who enjoy lighter-roasted, cleanly crisp, brisk coffees with quietly engaging aromatic intrigue.

Name: Beachcomber Blend
Review: ong>A classic espresso, roundly balanced and just dark roasted enough to develop chocolate, plum-toned fruit and a gently pungent cedar.

Name: Kenya AA
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classic Kenya: bright but sweet, cleanly and pungently fruit-toned, softly floral and musky.

Name: Ethiopia Suke Quto Organic
Review: ong>A superb wet-processed southern Ethiopia coffee, softly tart yet roundly juicy, with a subtle yet astounding range of aroma and flavor notes.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidamo growing region, south-central Ethiopia.

Name: Espresso Blend Spring 15
Review: ong>A fine all-around espresso: deep, balanced and complex as a straight shot with impressive presence in milk.

Name: S.O. Espresso Costa Rica Chayote
Review: ong>Should make a particularly appealing and accessible cappuccino. As a straight shot may come across as a bit too tart for some but just right for those who enjoy the new American style of espresso.
Coffee Origin: Los Robles de Naranjo, West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Sumatra Lake Tawar
Review: ong>This moderately dark-roasted Sumatra rewards patient attention to its quiet, layered complexity.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Esmeralda Leon Natural Geisha
Review: ong>A dried-in-the-fruit Gesha with all of the depth, range and complexity of the type held in a structural matrix of accessible balance and restraint.
Coffee Origin: CaÃ±as Verdes, Boquete growing region, western Panama.

Name: Thai Single-Origin Espresso Blend (A4+A5)
Review: ong>A smooth, balanced espresso, gently complex in the small cup and chocolaty in milk.

Name: Natural Process Thailand Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a richly chocolate- and fruit-toned espresso with a crisply drying edge.

Name: Natural Process Thailand Coffee
Review: ong>Displays a hint of the earthy, cedary pungency of Sumatra coffees, pleasingly enveloped in sweetness.

Name: Shilcho Ethiopia, Red Cherry Initiative
Review: ong>This classic southern Ethiopia wet-processed profile balances floral and fresh-fruit sweetness with a crisp, cocoa-edged briskness. For those who enjoy sweetness without simplicity.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya AB Kiruga
Review: ong>A delicate but complete version of the great Kenya profile, elegant in its juxtaposition of sweet, honeyish fruit and flowers with a lightly brisk, gently drying mouthfeel.

Name: Honduras Santa Barbara Las Brisas, Denis Teruel
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a gently pungent, resonant Central America cup with pleasing mouthfeel and distinct chocolate.

Name: Guatemala Acatenango Gesha
Review: ong>A quiet but still vivacious and distinctive version of the rare and always surprising Gesha profile.

Name: Ethiopia Konga
Review: ong>The slightly fermenty, cidery note complicates a pleasingly light and lively fruit-and-flowers profile. Lovers of delicately fruity but crisp white wines should particularly enjoy this cup.
Coffee Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Lomi Tasha Worka, Ethiopia
Review: ong>A particularly deep and complex version of the great wet-processed Yirgacheffe profile: The incense-like aromatic wood note gives resonance and depth to the pungent fruit and lush flowers.

Name: Lauraâs Reserve SL-28
Review: ong>Big, ringing, classic coffee. The Bourbon trees of Central and South America probably first gave North American culture the archetype of the classic coffee, with its sweet, juicy brightness, full mouthfeel, and richly layered flavor. Here the Bourbon-derived East Africa SL28 variety brought half-way around the world to Hawaii returns to this classic profile.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, âBig Islandâ of Hawaii.

Name: FlatIron Medium
Review: ong>The floral, cocoa and crisply sweet citrus character of a classic Yirgacheffe at a very good price.

Name: Kenya Kia Kiamarigo AA
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the peculiar intensity of certain Kenya coffees, in which a very sweet yet dry berry note dominates in a profile simultaneously juicy and tartly brisk.

Name: Parisi Espresso
Review: ong>The lively persistence in milk may attract caffÃ¨-latte drinkers, while the straight shot offers brightness and intensity for enthusiasts of lighter-roasted espressos.

Name: Kenya Mbeguka AA
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classically sweet, pungently bright, vivaciously lively Kenya.

Name: Organic Colombia Fondo Paez
Review: ong>A richly low-toned, chocolate-and-nut-nuanced cup with impressive social and environmental credentials.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Semeon Abay Ethiopia
Review: ong>A particularly intense, sweetly juicy, vividly complex version of the Ethiopian natural profile for those with substantial coffee budgets.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Rukira AB
Review: ong>An extraordinary version of an extraordinary origin: intense and distinctive, yet poised, suave, balanced.

Name: Doi Chaang Arabica
Review: ong>Those who avoid assertively bright intensity and prefer instead a gently lively, sweetly nuanced cup like this one.

Name: Auromar Camilina Geisha
Review: ong>This great dried-in-the-fruit Gesha displays solid, flawless structure and stunningly intricate aromatics. Particularly engaging is the way the lush fruit works against spicier and drier notes like the unsweetened chocolate and tea rose.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: ong>Itâs hard to imagine a more table-pleasingly versatile holiday coffee than this smooth, round, yet exhilaratingly complex blend, but aficionados also may find it worth seeking out for its complex expression of the classic Bourbon style.

Name: Ethiopia Wenago Natural
Review: ong>Those who can handle an almost impossibly sweet, lavishly fruit-toned coffee ringing with symphonic complexity.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia.

Name: Panama Geisha Holiday Blend
Review: ong>The combination of a very distinguished wet-processed Gesha and a dried-in-the-fruit or natural Gesha nets an original high-end holiday blend that should both engage aficionados and pleasingly surprise the uninitiated.

Name: Panama Esmeralda Especial Geisha Bosque 2
Review: ong>An exceptional choice for the lovers of richly complex, pleasingly bittersweet beverages; bitters-heavy mixed drinks and cocktails, to offer only one example.

Name: Gratitude Special Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy mulled wine or similar beverages that merge the tart, the sweet and the savory may particularly enjoy this unusual blend.

Name: Nicaragua Pacamara Reserve Los Congos
Review: ong>Those who prefer richness and low-toned intricacy in a coffee with a distinctive sensory profile and big, dramatic beans.
Coffee Origin: San Fernando, Nueva Segovia region, Nicaragua.

Name: Kenya Muthonjo AA
Review: ong>Buoyantly floral- and fruit-toned aromatics complicate a rich, intense, sweetly drying structure in this fine Kenya.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: ong>Brings an appropriately savory-sweet, spicy presence to the holiday cup.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: ong>Lovers of the richly and sweetly bright; a classic cup on steroids.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: ong>The engaging juxtaposition of sweet and dry tendencies in this seasonal blend resolve with particularly satisfying richness in an unusually long and complex finish.

Name: California Grown Coffee: Caturra 2014 Crop
Review: ong>A curiosity from close to home, this first-ever California-grown coffee is impressively balanced, deep and quietly intricate.

Name: Kenya Kaiguri Peaberry
Review: ong>A Kenya for aficionados, with the deep, sweetly tart, slightly savory structure of the style supporting a distinctive set of aromatics. The interesting tobacco note suggests the fragrantly fruity style of tobacco called perique.

Name: Guatemala Volcano Coffee
Review: ong>Those who prefer depth and resonance to acidity and brightness in a rich, balanced cup.

Name: 85 Degree Guatemala Espresso
Review: ong>Those who prefer a tactfully medium-dark-roasted espresso with depth and a sweet, low-toned set of aromatics.

Name: Guatemala Jimenez Vasquez micro-lot
Review: ong>Those who enjoy quiet complexity in a low-toned though resonant classic Guatemala cup.

Name: Yirgacheffe Sweet Blend
Review: ong>Those who value a crisp cup with bitterness balancing sweetness and floral and cocoaish aromatics.

Name: Ethiopia Ninety Plus Hachira N2
Review: ong>Fireworks and subtle grace in a striking cup that should both comfort and excite.

Name: Perci Red Panama Gesha
Review: ong>A very light-roasted presentation encourages contemplation of a dried-in-the-fruit green coffee as absolutely pure as it is vibrant and intricate.

Name: Kenya Karagoto
Review: ong>A particularly fine, floral-toned version of the classic Kenya profile, delicate and giddy in its sweet flowers and berry working over drier, more savory suggestions.

Name: Nekisse Natural Process Ethiopia
Review: ong>An engagingly lush yet cleanly crisp, intricately layered version of the great Ethiopia natural or dried-in-the-fruit cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Costa Rica Santa Rosa 1900
Review: ong>hose who enjoy classic coffees with a round, deep, syrupy profile and quiet complexity.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica.

Name: Lycello Panama Gesha
Review: ong>Light roasting develops the delicate, refreshing, very gently tart character of this coffee. The distinct pear-like notes, crisp yet juicy, are particularly attractive and unusual.

Name: Sulawesi Toarco Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who prefer the low-toned exotic in a round, resonant cup.
Coffee Origin: Toraja growing region, south-central Sulawesi, Indonesia.

Name: Java Sunda Hejo Micro-Lot
Review: ong>Those who value the rather rough, earthy style of Indonesian coffees.

Name: Costa Rica La Nena Red Honey
Review: ong>An attractive coffee for those who prefer naturally sweet coffees with quiet acidity but gently lively aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Central Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Nagy Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a sweet, refreshing, light-roasted cup from an unusual origin.

Name: Throttle Espresso
Review: ong>A balanced, lively straight shot, but particularly fine in shorter milk: Should make a superb cappuccino.

Name: Kenya Gondo
Review: ong>

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Gutiti
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the intense, complex flowers and tart, sweet vivacity of a classic Yirgacheffe.
Coffee Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia.

Name: Ulos Batak Sumatra Peaberry
Review: ong>Knock-out Sumatra. As elegant as it is earthy and exotic.

Name: Espresso Nuevo
Review: ong>A fine classic espresso in the traditional American mode: Chocolaty, crisp while avoiding brightness, authoritative in milk.

Name: Emilse Luna Colombia
Review: ong>A straightforward, refreshing cup in the traditional American breakfast coffee mode.

Name: Ethiopia Konga
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big, fruity red table wines. This is a dried-in-the-fruit coffee that makes no apologies for its lush, brandy-soaked sweetness.
Coffee Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya Kieni
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the engagingly different in coffee. This is not a typical Kenya, but it is certainly a pleasing and distinctive one.

Name: Papua New Guinea Kimel
Review: ong>A subtly original coffee that rewards patience. A fine choice for those who prefer quiet, nuanced depth to assertive brightness.
Coffee Origin: Wahgi Valley, Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea.

Name: Colombia Cauca
Review: ong>Those who enjoy quiet balance in a classic lighter-roasted Latin-American breakfast cup.
Coffee Origin: Valle de Cauca Department, southwestern Colombia.

Name: Kenya AA Top 405A Espresso
Review: ong>Shows most complexity and definition as a straight shot, but also exciting with milk. Should please aficionados and beginners alike.

Name: Seasonal Mini-Me Yirgacheffe Washed
Review: ong>So intricately lively and silkily buoyant a coffee, it almost levitates out of the cup. A great Yirgacheffe.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Deri Kochoha WP
Review: ong>Those who enjoy intense, delicately complex, exotic coffees.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya AA 405A
Review: ong>A roast at the dark end of medium brings the chocolate forward and intensifies the signature Kenya flavor note, a brisk but deeply sweet berry sensation.

Name: Ethiopia Dry Process Yirgacheffe Konga
Review: ong>Those who enjoy deeply resonant floral and chocolate character in a brisk, slightly roast-toned presentation that quiets the usual Yirgacheffe acidity.
Coffee Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Costa Rica Finca El Llano
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classic American breakfast cup with quietly rounded acidity and pleasing nuance.
Coffee Origin: San Marcos, Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica.

Name: Panama Mama Cata Natural
Review: ong>Extraordinary coffee, intense yet balanced, supporting a giddy avalanche of aromatic complexity.

Name: High Mountain Red Bourbon
Review: ong>A classic coffee, grandly structured but balanced, with a massive but gracefully expressed range of aroma and flavor.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, âBig Islandâ of Hawaii.

Name: Nicaragua Pacamara Reserve Los Congos
Review: ong>Those who prefer depth and resonance to brightness in an engagingly complex coffee.
Coffee Origin: San Fernando, Nueva Segovia region, Nicaragua.

Name: Panama Duncan Natural Gesha
Review: ong>Lush and complex in flavor and aroma, crisp and bittersweet in structure, a remarkable cup for coffee adventurers patient enough to navigate its layered intricacy.
Coffee Origin: El Salto, Boquete growing region, Panama.

Name: Guatemala Acatenango Gesha
Review: ong>A fine variation on the great Gesha fruit, flower and cacao complex, supported by a structure simultaneously crisp and syrupy.

Name: El Socorro Pacamara Guatemala
Review: ong>Light roasting allows this Pacamaraâs gently unusual character full expression.

Name: Esmeralda Leon Natural Geisha
Review: ong>A fine variation on the great Gesha profile, with the full suite of Gesha aromatics, but showing a bit more chocolate and less floral than is typical for this distinguished variety.
Coffee Origin: CaÃ±as Verdes, Boquete growing region, western Panama.

Name: Colombia Cerro Azul Enano
Review: ong>Some may prefer this quieter version of the Gesha cup; still exotic and complex, but a bit more chocolate, fewer flowers, less forward acidity. And for a coffee this distinguished and this close in expression to the famous and rare Gesha, an excellent value: in other words, quite a bit of Geshaness for relatively little money.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Kenya AA Kirimahiga
Review: ong>A quiet but vibrant rendition of the great Kenya SL 28 profile: juicy, gently pungent, with a shimmer of backgrounded flowers.

Name: Nicaragua Mozonte âElephant Beanâ Natural
Review: ong>Those aficionados interested in sampling a particularly fine version of the huge-beaned Maracaturra.

Name: Imperial Reserve Juan Pena La Papaya Washed
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a pure, subtle, gently sweet-toned cup.

Name: Reindeer Blend
Review: ong>A roundly sweet, cleanly expressed dark roast nicely develops chocolate and raisiny fruit notes plus some bonus nuance for the holidays.

Name: Kenya Kigwandi AA
Review: ong>Those who appreciate big, sweet, resonating brightness and layered nuance in a superb Kenya.

Name: Aeknauli Sumatra
Review: ong>Fine choice for lovers of the traditional earthy Sumatra cup who want an upgrade to a, well, elegantly earthy Sumatra cup.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Doi Chaang Arabica
Review: ong>Coffee from an unusual origin with good balance and quiet intrigue in the aroma/flavor complex.

Name: Loma Alta El Salvador
Review: ong>Those who enjoy crisply dry, spice- and floral-toned white table wines.

Name: Rwanda Tumba Cocatu
Review: ong>Those who prefer bittersweetness and depth to tart brightness in a classic medium-roast cup.

Name: Ethiopia Homacho Waeno
Review: ong>Anyone who loves coffee. Flawless and complete, yet resonant with aromatic drama and complexity.
Coffee Origin: Aleta Wondo, Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Colombia Granja Esperanza Gesha AAA
Review: ong>Enjoy this spectacular version of the still rare and pricy Gesha/Geisha if you enjoy big, bright acidity and lush, almost limitless complexity. (And if your coffee budget can handle it).
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Ethiopia Homacho Waeno
Review: ong>Those who value a coffee with delicate acidity and aromatics alive with a generous and profound range of floral, fruit and cacao/nut notes.
Coffee Origin: Aleta Wondo, Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Guatemala Finca El Valle Antigua
Review: ong>A balanced, quietly complete coffee that gracefully embodies the softly pungent, sweetly seductive tendencies associated with the classic Guatemala Antigua cup.

Name: Ethiopia Wotona Bultuma
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a light-roasted, sweetly honey- and floral-toned coffee with enough guava-like pungency to give the cup depth and authority.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: MIG Washing Station Gikongoro Rwanda
Review: ong>Those who enjoy crisply sweet, delicate coffees alive with floral, nut and fresh-cut aromatic wood notes.

Name: Rwanda Buremura
Review: ong>Lovers of sturdy coffees balancing sweet, bitter, savory and tart sensations with quietly engaging aromatics.

Name: Nicaragua Las Hermanas FTO
Review: ong>A fine choice for those who enjoy a coffee with a roast note that complements without overwhelming the underlying character of the coffee.

Name: Mexico FTO
Review: ong>Those who enjoy coffees with a brisk, bracing character that derives from the green coffee itself rather than from darker roasting.

Name: Los Guardianes Peru FTO
Review: ong>A tactful dark-end-of-medium roast develops the savory-sweet richness of this Peru with its chocolate, pungent-sweet date-like fruit and whiff of musky lily.

Name: Honey Margarita Colombia
Review: ong>The honey processing and a darkish medium roast together develop an almost Sumatra-like fusion of sweet fruit, aromatic wood, deep, perfumy flowers and a hint of clay-like earth.

Name: Kenya Mathew Mugo
Review: ong>Those who appreciate the powerful but sweet acidity of a very pure, finely nuanced Kenya.

Name: Organic Ethiopian Banko Natural
Review: ong>An unusually deep and dessert-like version of the great fruit-and-flowers Yirgacheffe profile.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Organic Ethiopian Hama Special Prep
Review: ong>Delicate, lemony and floral, sweet yet dry, this coffee may particularly appeal to lovers of analogous styles of white table wines.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya Nyeri
Review: ong>Those who love the sweet, juicy intensity of big acidity, in this case wrapped in the resonance of complex floral, chocolate and bright fruit.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Borboya Washing Station
Review: ong>A pleasingly pungent and crisp version of the great Yirgacheffe profile; here deep-toned cocoa, nut and berry move forward, backgrounding the still lively floral notes.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Othaya Peaberry
Review: ong>A tactfully roast-rounded Kenya: gently bright, gracefully nuanced, chocolaty.

Name: Kenya AA Wanjengi
Review: ong>A quiet but complex and original Kenya that should please those who prefer resonance to assertive brightness.

Name: Konga Natural Ethiopia
Review: ong>Lovers of cognacs and fine American rye and corn whiskies may particularly enjoy this big, sweetly dry, complex coffee.
Coffee Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya AA Giakanja
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big, resonant red table wines with both oak and fruit.

Name: Ethiopia Cheleâ Lektu
Review: ong>A balanced structure supports a particularly sweet, graceful rendition of Yirgacheffe flowers, citrus and chocolate.

Name: Costa Rica CafetÃ­n San Martin 2000m
Review: ong>Classic American cup: bright but sweet, balanced, engaging, breakfasty.

Name: Misty Valley Ethiopia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy delicate but authoritative beverages. Should make a very fine, refreshing iced coffee.

Name: El Socorro Maracaturra
Review: ong>The quiet complexity and balanced resonance characteristic of this fine hybrid variety.

Name: Miravalle Honduras
Review: ong>A brisk, delicately lively coffee for fall mornings.

Name: Ethiopia Boke Natural Grade 1 Espresso
Review: ong>A powerful balance of brightness and depth supports a startling and original display of aromatic complexity. The intensity of the aromatic resin notes in particular may not be for everyone, but single-origin espresso aficionados should not miss this one.
Coffee Origin: Boke, Gamo Gofa Zone, Southern Ethiopia.

Name: Amyâs Blend
Review: ong>Complete, balanced version of a blend with an inspiring story and a good cause. A fat, deep resonance of sensation is perhaps its most striking sensory feature.

Name: Colombia Inza Cauca
Review: ong>Those who prefer the deep, low-toned, chocolaty style of Colombia coffee.
Coffee Origin: Valle de Cauca Department, western Colombia

Name: Sumatra Tano Batak
Review: ong>An excellent choice for upscaling Sumatra lovers as well as anyone who enjoys an exotic cup, simultaneously lush yet crisp.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Gutiti
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a dramatically aromatic and crisply refreshing cup.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya Ruarai AB
Review: ong>Fine example of the great Kenya profile: complex, sweet though dry, juicy but grown-up.

Name: Kochoha Espresso
Review: ong>This is the newer style of American espresso at its finest: bright, exciting, utterly distinctive in the small cup and in milk.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Deri Kochoha Ethiopia
Review: ong>Extraordinarily sweetly bright and refreshing cup, a spring morning in September.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Costa Rica Cerro San Luis Honey
Review: ong>Those who value a combination of floral sweetness and crisp, nutty chocolate in a balanced, quietly rich cup.
Coffee Origin: San Luis de Grecia, central Costa Rica.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Giakanja
Review: ong>A superb coffee in virtually every respect, grandly structured and original in aromatics, with a fine balance between honey-like sweetness and pungent and tart notes.

Name: Perci N2 L39
Review: ong>Great sweetness and extravagant aromatics in a rare and exotic coffee.

Name: Yirgacheffe Aricha Natural G1
Review: ong>A sweet, cleanly fermenty dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia profile on steroids: big, giddy, grandly lyrical.

Name: Sumatra Tano Batak
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the new style of Sumatra, still rich and deep, but elegant and refined in its chocolate, pungent citrus and aromatic wood character.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Rustyâs Hawaiian
Review: ong>A very light-roasted, flawlessly prepared coffee for those who value purity, silken delicacy and fresh, crisp aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing district, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Colombia Granja La Esperanza Grand Cru Mokka
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in enjoying a delicate, subtly exotic version of the very rare Mokka variety of Arabica; anyone who values subtlety, purity and balance in the cup.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Gayo Natural
Review: ong>A fine, elegantly complex dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia profile, with particularly complex floral notes and just a hint of rum-like spirits.

Name: Manzano Honey Process El Salvador
Review: ong>Those who enjoy delicate balance in a finely structured, quietly complex cup.

Name: Panama Ironman Camilina Geisha
Review: ong>Anyone who can afford it. The wet-processed Gesha profile, however complex and extraordinary, can be too bright and drying for many coffee drinkers, but here the dried-in-the-fruit or natural processing rounds and deepens the acidity â and everything else â in this utterly amazing, if dauntingly expensive, coffee.

Name: Panama Estate Reserve: Elida Estate Natural
Review: ong>Christmas in September. The dark chocolate, ripe fruit and hints of mint and warm spice suggest holiday pleasures.

Name: Byronâs Maracaturra Natural Nicaragua
Review: ong>Aficionados may enjoy sampling an unusual variety and its enormous beans, but everyone with a refined coffee sweet tooth should enjoy the natural sweetness and tropical fruit (and drink) suggestions proposed by aroma and flavor.

Name: Panama Chiriqui Finca Santa Teresa Geisha
Review: ong>Those interested in sampling the giddy intricacy of the Gesha profile in its unusual honey-process incarnation.

Name: Costa Rica Cerro San Luis Natural
Review: ong>Crisp cacao nib and cedar suggestions balance gently lush lily and brandy in this finely understated dried-in-the-fruit profile.
Coffee Origin: San Luis de Grecia, central Costa Rica.

Name: Panama La Berlina Typica Natural
Review: ong>Those who enjoy natural sweetness and gentle aromatic surprise in a coffee that proposes the classic while quietly transcending it.

Name: Costa Rica Flor de Santos Bourbon Natural
Review: ong>No super fireworks here, but a fine, balanced, crisply sweet structure with a svelte and very engaging range of lightly and cleanly brandy-toned aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica.

Name: Panama NPGE Perci N2
Review: ong>A splendid dried-in-the-fruit Gesha, crisply sweet in structure, precise and elegant in the breadth and depth of its aromatic suggestion.

Name: Panama Elida Natural Lot #5
Review: ong>Meditative coffee lovers. This quiet but balanced and subtle dried-in-the-fruit coffee encourages patient, attentive drinking.

Name: Finca Angelina Costa Rica Honey
Review: ong>Those who enjoy sweetness and delicacy without simplicity.
Coffee Origin: Los Robles de Naranjo, West Valley, Costa Rica.

Name: El Salvador Finca Himalaya Honey
Review: ong>Cabernet drinkers in particular may enjoy this big, rich honey-processed cup.

Name: Costa Rica Las Lajas Perla Negra Natural
Review: ong>Those who prefer depth, resonance and balance to bright assertion in a quietly nuanced cup.
Coffee Origin: Central Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: El Salvador Malacara B
Review: ong>The sweet yet dry fruit character of Bourbon-derived varieties of Arabica presents here with subtle understatement that should please those who value gentle acidity, full mouthfeel and quietly distinctive aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Volcan de Santa Ana region, El Salvador.

Name: Costa Rica Lobos 1 Rio Jorca
Review: ong>Sophisticated flowers and chocolate, crisp and suave.
Coffee Origin: San Ignacio Acosta, Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica.

Name: Guatemala La Bolsa
Review: ong>A very complete coffee; its natural, chocolaty sweetness may make it a good choice for those interested in transitioning from sweetener and whitener to taking their coffee black.

Name: Kathakwa Kenya
Review: ong>A classic Kenya, elegantly dry yet sweetly juicy, floral, chocolaty.

Name: Lomi Tasha Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>An unapologetic, thoroughly engaging version of the Ethiopian dried-in-the-fruit or ânaturalâ processed profile, alive with whisky-like suggestions and unorthodox complexity.

Name: El Salvador Cerro Las Ranas Espresso
Review: ong>A strong-gestured espresso: authoritative and complex as a straight shot, pronounced in short milk, and impressively persistent in longer milk.

Name: Seasonal 2014 Mini-Me Yirgacheffe Washed
Review: ong>Lush flowers, brisk citrus and savory depth in a complex and unusually bracing version of the great Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: El Salvador Las Mercedes Pacamara Honey
Review: ong>Anyone who enjoys complex essays in juxtapositions of sweet and savory should enjoy this coffee, but aficionados may be particularly interested in possible readings of impact of variety and processing method: The savory/sweet richness may be owing to the impact of the Pacamara variety; the honey processing doubtless further contributes to sweetness and complexity.

Name: Seasonal 2014 Cocoa Sweet Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy dry, brisk versions of a chocolate-toned espresso.

Name: Organic Fair Trade Espresso
Review: ong>Grapefruit and chocolate dominate pleasingly in a tactfully dark-roasted organic and Fair Trade espresso.

Name: Hawaii Isla Espresso
Review: ong>A big, grand espresso in the old, complexly chocolaty style. Some may find the pronounced drying mouthfeel in the otherwise fine finish distracting; others may not care.
